title: Designing a Curriculum
segmentation: Good afternoon everybody.
First of all, thank you very much for the kind invitation.
We're really honored to be here and share our idea about the future of the architectural education.
And today we would like to present our project which we called designing our curriculum.
So first, my colleague Mario will start and then I will continue.
OK, so.
OK.
So a specter is counting architecture students all over the world, a specter of productivity.
Sleeping is for losers.
The office moved into bed, looking busy is the new black.
Our project proposal is situated in the field of architectural education, addresses the urge of its re imagination.
The architecture curriculum is, broadly speaking, modeled as a simulation of market oriented professional practice.
Design Studio projects match office settings involving real work, real hours designing real topologists intervening in the real locations only outside of the real market at school.

Education is the practice of simulating professional real life has brought new forms of bottom up self exploitation to schools, portfolio, biography, visibility oriented production, creating an intrapreneurial sell for understanding oneself as a potential to be realized through the market, merging life and work.
Because architecture is a calling another profession.
Sorry.
Still, curriculum is not something given, it's something designed and therefore something that can be redesigned.
This is a proposal for inverting the logic of Design Studio in architectural school.
Instead of designing buildings, taking curriculum as an object of design instead of designing objects.
Designing subjectivities enrolls architect can take instead of designing architectural forms, designing forms of architectural connectivity and organization.
Only in the moment in which students become aware of their historical specificity as students, the struggle can set off.
Education as a universality.
Sorry or abstract category happens only in its concreteness.

Students and teachers, by constantly playing the role of the future, architect the present tense, the historical specificity of architecture students as subjects as producers as workers and as a collective ITI is neutralized.

In his book The Pedagogy of the oppressed Brazilian educator, Paulo Freitas said it is essential for the press to realize that when they accept the struggle for humanisation they also set from that moment their total responsibility for the struggle.

Starting from this point, we claim that radical transformation of University has to come from students and not only in the form of the revolt or protest, but in the form of active thinking of what studying actually is.
We are interested in how the concept of struggle can be part of the curriculum.
In other words, how can architecture students by the means of design move from creating hypothetical situations towards creating their actual ones?
Being urgency and kind of a teacher and ignorant schoolmaster might be necessary.
Now more than ever.

In other words, teacher as an emancipator instead of a teacher as a knowledge authoritie by giving students a task to design their own curriculums, the teacher challenges the students to question their own actuality, labor, modes of production and forms of engagement.
So just continue with talking about the possible outcomes and the way we see this project actually becoming.
So designing a curriculum is a proposal for an experiment in architectural education, and by that we mean that we take the architectural education as a real situation of the architectural student.
So it's not something about that.
It's not about becoming architect in the future, but it's about studying architecture now.
And what does that mean in terms of subjectivity of an architectural student?
And it is imagined the proposal is a workshop that ideally hacks into the existing University based design studio and kind of expand expand the scope of imitating architectural practice.
Alternatively, it can be organized as an independence workshop as a summer school as an elective class or so on.
Um?
The.
What can be the possible outcomes outcomes of this project?

We imagine new curriculums, new models of curriculums, both abstract and concrete, new forms of student collective practices starting from the curriculum does not necessarily have to lead to inventing a new curriculum, but it can also mean a new student, institutions or reclamation of an existing institutions of performance, a strike or whatever.
So we see both bureaucratic aspect of it and performative aspect of the project.
Um?
In order to illustrate this idea, we want to give a few examples.
Which are some of our projects that we completed.
Some of the projects from our school in DTH to Rick.
This is project for a public stage called Nautilus Construct which we ran as elective class in the both universities in for architecture faculty for architecture in Scorpion in Zurich.
And it was basically built within one year.
The whole project lasted one year and basically the project started as critical engagement with the city.
Or let's say, kind of like an answer to the current state sponsored rebuilding of Skopia with which kind of tries to reproduce symbols dating back to antiquity.
So kind of you have a situation where the state kind of hijacks the current cultural production.
So we set.
Let's invent a brief.
Let's invent a client.
Let's invent a project and kind of act from the school within the real world.
So this is one kind of.
Project which resulted into this, I would say quite successful example and it kind of worked well as a as a teaching practice as well.
Other project which so the other way from from built form to kind of more exploration into, let's say publishing, teaching and so on.

This is an example of a design semester, so it's architectural studio which was led at TTH, touring with in the studio of Christian Carrots, in collaboration with the German architect an Arno Brandl Huber, and it serves as a possible role model for us.
So what happened here is that this studio was called legislating architecture sites, so.

Which looked into the relationship between building regulations and codes and the production of architecture asking how the certain laws determine our possibilities as architects and how can architects internship those loss?
So what it they took is this?
Kind of they developed a graphic techniques.
The students develop the graphic language based on very typical model that works in Switzerland, which is the referendum and they organized a design.
A series of posters, propaganda posters which they kind of protested within real space of the city they talked to like Rio City authorities an this were so at the end they had to kind of.
Organize their own actions for a possible referendum so this.
At the end resulted in in a video in a film resulted in a publication.
And resulted in the performance.
And this would we imagine that our project could kind of follow this kind of possible outcomes of production.
And post production.
And finally, our claim for the future of architecture.

So we claim that the future of architecture might not be in creating new spatial models, but in reorganizing the institutions and reclaiming critical roles by turning the current order upside down in his timeless as say, author as a producer about their, Benjamin argued that we do not need to change only the content or what we design, but production itself or how we design with this project proposal.
We want to emphasize that it is important to understand the work of an architect not only in relation to architecture as a built environment.
But also in relation to all those invisible infrastructures and institutions that define and regulate the profession.
Thank you very much.
